subject: On the completeness of representables
key_passage: Your representable perspective contains something deeper than you may have intended. If we know how an object responds to every representable probe, do we not know everything about that object?
significance: First formulation of the completeness insight

subject: Re: On the completeness of representables
key_passage: Your observation intrigues me. I had thought of representables as offering viewpoints, but you suggest they exhaust all possible information. Can you make this precise?
significance: Dray encourages Strand to develop the idea

subject: Toward a proof of completeness
key_passage: I believe I have the outline. The key is that the Yoneda map is injective: different objects must differ in at least one probe response. And it is surjective onto natural transformations: every way of assigning probe responses coherently corresponds to an object.
significance: Core insight of the Probing Lemma

subject: Re: Toward a proof
key_passage: Your argument is compelling but requires careful verification of naturality. The coherence conditions must hold for each transformation of probes.
significance: Dray identifies the key technical challenge

subject: On probing and naturality
key_passage: I have been studying your work on natural transformations. It seems crucial to my own: the probing principle requires that probe responses transform coherently. Your naturality conditions are precisely what I need.
significance: Connection between Strand and Tross work

subject: Re: On probing and naturality
key_passage: Your letter delights me. Yes, naturality ensures coherence of perspective shifts. If your probing lemma holds, it would unify much of what we have all been building.

subject: On the manuscript
key_passage: I enclose my manuscript 'On Probing and Representation' for your review. It formalizes what we discussed in 948. I hope it does justice to your foundational work on representables.

subject: Re: On the manuscript
key_passage: Your work is rigorous and illuminating. I have only one concern: you claim embeddings capture complete information, but in practice we have only finite probes. How do you address the gap between theory and application?
significance: The core objection leading to the 968 debate

subject: On theoretical vs. practical completeness
key_passage: You raise a fundamental point. The theorem proves theoretical completeness—infinite probes determine objects exactly. Practical embeddings approximate this with finite probes. The theorem justifies the approximation: we know what we are approximating toward.

subject: On the embedding map
key_passage: I have now proved that the Yoneda embedding is full and faithful. This means: not only do probe-response profiles uniquely determine objects, but every morphism between objects is also captured by how it transforms probe responses.

subject: Re: On the embedding map
key_passage: Full and faithful! This is the completeness we sought. The embedding loses nothing—neither objects nor the relations between them. Congratulations on this achievement.

subject: On publishing our exchange
key_passage: I propose we publish our exchange on completeness as a formal debate. The question of whether embeddings are approximate or exact deserves public examination.

subject: Re: On publishing our exchange
key_passage: I agree. Let us structure it as: your position that completeness is theoretical, my position that it validates practical embeddings. The resolution: finite approximation approaches infinite exactness.

subject: On your declining health
key_passage: I hear your strength wanes. Know that your work on representables made my Probing Lemma possible. The field we built together will outlast us both.

subject: The Probing Theorem complete
key_passage: After two decades, I have completed the definitive proof. 'The Probing Theorem' is now archived as STR-002. It shows that probe-response determines identity completely—for objects, morphisms, and natural transformations alike.

subject: Re: The Probing Theorem
key_passage: Your theorem stands as one of the great achievements of our generation. From Vold's passage diagrams through my uncle Pemlik's constellations, through Dray's representables and my naturality principle—you have unified it all.

subject: On the death of Lorren Dray
key_passage: Lorren Dray died today. She lived to see my theorem completed but did not live to see its implications fully explored. I dedicate the theorem to her memory.
significance: Death of Dray Year 968 (Strand misremembers the date in his grief)
